biogHist.abstract: Lombadina, on the Dampier Peninsula, was a Mission established by the Catholic Diocese of Broome and run by the Society of the Catholic Apostolate (Pallottines) from 1909. It accommodated Aboriginal babies, children and young people. The Sisters of St John of God ran the Mission school from around 1917 to the 1970s. From 1905, the head of the government departments responsible for Aboriginal welfare was the guardian of children at Lombadina and from 1972 the chief executive officer of the Department for Community Welfare was the guardian of any children at Lombadina who were deemed to be 'native wards' or 'wards of the State'. In 1975, Lombadina became a self-governing community and its role in institutionalised child 'care' ended. However, it continued to receive government support as a subsidised centre under child welfare legislation until 1988.

chronItem.event: Location - Lombadinawas located on the Dampier Peninsula

descriptiveNote.p: The Pallottines (Society of the Catholic Apostolates) ran Lombadina as part of the Catholic Diocese of Broome.
The Commissioner of Native Affairs was the legal guardian of children at Lombadina.
The Chief Protector of Aborigines was the legal guardian of children at Lombadina.

cpfRelation.relationEntry: State Archives Collection of Western Australia (1829 - )

descriptiveNote.p: The State Archives Collection of Western Australia contains records, including items that name residents of Lombadina and administration items.

cpfRelation.relationEntry: Western Australian Government Records relating to Child Welfare and Protection (1894 - )
Department of Aboriginal Affairs [predecessors], Records, Department of Aboriginal Affairs (1886 - 2004)
Sisters of St John of God, Kimberley, Records (1895 - )

descriptiveNote.p: Sydney Hadley, who had run the Forrest River and Sunday Island Missions, had held the pastoral lease at Lombadina since 1884.

cpfRelation.relationEntry: Sisters of St John of God (1895 - )

descriptiveNote.p: The Sisters of St John of God ran the school at Lombadina.
The Commissioner of Native Welfare was the legal guardian of children at Lombadina until 1963 when he could regulate the 'care' of Aboriginal children.

cpfRelation.relationEntry: Department for Community Welfare, State of Western Australia (1972 - 1985)

descriptiveNote.p: The Chief Executive Officer of the Department for Community Welfare, was the legal guardian of any children at Lombadina who were deemed 'native wards' or 'wards of the state'.

resourceRelation.relationEntry: A big photo album: the archive of the Sisters of St John of God

archref.unittitle: A big photo album: the archive of the Sisters of St John of God
archref.abstract: 'A big photo album: the archive of the Sisters of St John of God' is an online news item from ABC Kimberley. It shows pictures of Aboriginal children and adults, and is about the collection of 34,000 photographs held by the Sisters of St John of God at the Heritage Centre in Broome, Western Australia.
